The Australian Wheat Board's commercial wheat marketing and financing functions are to be transferred to a wholly grower‐owned holding company and its subsidiary. The subsidiaries will include a trading subsidiary and a pooling subsidiary. Shares in the holding company will be issued in two classes, A class and B class. Of course, as the member for O'Connor has pointed out, it is those holdings in the A class where the real power will reside on these issues.

One A class share will be issued to each grower and the Wheat Industry Fund will be converted to B class shares. The shares will be distributed to those with an equity in the fund in proportion to their equity holding. The single desk system will remain, at least for now, until we work out some competition policy issues. The Australian Wheat Board will continue to manage the Wheat Industry Fund, and will be accountable to the parliament and to the industry. The holding company will of course operate under the Corporations Law.

Australia is the fourth largest wheat exporter in the world, trailing only the USA, Europe and Canada. Our wheat producers produce, on average, 15 million tonnes each year of which around 60,000 tonnes is produced in my own electorate, not a significant amount but certainly an important amount to my electorate. Most of that is grown in the Merriwa and Quirindi and surrounding areas. Of the 15 million tonnes that I have mentioned, some 85 per cent of that is exported. So no other country is as dependent on the wheat export market as is Australia.

The Wheat Marketing Amendment Bill 1997 is a very important bill to the nation and indeed to my electorate. That is why I rise today to support the amendment put forward by our shadow minister, the member for Burke (Mr O'Keefe). It does appear extraordinary that, with so many issues remaining outstanding, as the member for O'Connor has articulated so well, the government should be proceeding to the second reading of this bill in the House when at the very same time the Senate Rural and Regional Affairs and Transport Committee is holding an inquiry into the bill. The committee has identified the outstanding issues. The nature of the evidence being placed before the Senate committee and the various concerns being expressed in the media, in the community generally and, indeed, by the member for O'Connor, should have set the alarm bells ringing within the government.

The Senate committee is due to report to the Senate by 23 October so what is the rush on this bill? This is a process which effectively began back in 1989 and has essentially been driven by the Australian Labor Party. So our position in terms of this amendment is not one of opposition but one of a carefully, carefully approach. We support the main thrust of the bill but the industry is entitled to be extensively consulted and the Senate committee process is an appropriate forum for the airing of those concerns. It is a chance for the government to make amends for an earlier period where it has not been prepared to listen carefully enough to the concerns of the industry, and there certainly have been some concerns, Mr Deputy Speaker. One only needs to look at the screams coming from the Western Australians about the allocation of A class shares. I did not think that issue had been resolved but I thought the member for O'Connor said something that would indicate to me that maybe it has.

And then there was the member for O'Connor's submission to the Senate committee which he also mentioned. For those who have not read the submission, it is very extensive and it is very critical of the government's approach. From what I heard him say today that was only partly representative of that extensive submission. Of course, we are speaking here of the member for O'Connor, a member of the government, who represents an electorate which produces 60 per cent, as I understand it, of Australian wheat exports. I was disappointed that he did not answer my question when he was talking about his preparedness to speak openly on these issues, both before the Senate committee and publicly. When I asked him what the minister had to say about his concerns, he avoided the question. His submission to the committee, as I said, was extensive, and can best be described as a bombshell, as was his speech in here today.

TALK.START.PARA: —Maybe not a bombshell.

—Maybe not a bombshell. That is probably the wrong term, because the member for O'Connor is well‐known for criticising his own government, and has been criticising it on this issue for some months. I should not say it was a bombshell, but it certainly was a good shot at his own government in terms of the way it has approached this issue.

SPEECH.PARA: Just last Friday, the chairman of the Grains Committee of the New South Wales Farmers Association gave evidence before the Senate committee. He told the committee, and I quote:
The majority of our members have a strong view that what has been successful for nearly 60 years should mainly be left alone.

Some may see that as an extraordinary statement not reflecting the reality of today's world, the globalisation of the economy and all the rest. The point is that we have a bill before the House today which has many in the industry most concerned, but the government is not prepared to hold it over until those people have had the opportunity to put their case. The Senate committee is a perfect opportunity and again, I do not understand why the government is rushing this through before the Senate has given them that opportunity.

Too many questions remain unanswered to allow the passage of this bill through the House at this point: questions relating to competition policy and the single desk issue, and questions relating to whether the proposed statutory arrangements will run into problems with respect to World Trade Organisation negotiations and so on.

As I said earlier, Mr Deputy Speaker, I support the main thrust of the bill. It is an important part of a process which will deliver to the industry ownership and control of the Australian Wheat Board, and it provides a mechanism for maintaining at least the existing level of harvest payments. It will deliver greater commercial flexibility and will go some way toward making the industry players masters of their own destiny.

The industry has been the subject of a number of High Court rulings, Senate standing committee reports and Auditor‐General's reports, and two Industry Commission reports. I hope that we are at least partly on track to getting it right this time around. Allowing the Senate inquiry to proceed and make recommendations before this bill makes its passage through the House is one very effective way of ensuring that that will be the case. I commend the member for Burke's amendments to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Forrest, John, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I will attempt to answer, for his benefit, the very genuine concerns and questions of the member for Hunter (Mr Fitzgibbon). The Wheat Marketing Amendment Bill is an historic piece of legislation, and very important to an electorate like Mallee, which produces—and I will be kind—a lot more grain than Hunter. I am not churlish about this. My grain growing constituency have urged me very much to support this legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: The view needs to be adopted that this represents an enabling bill to start a process. The member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey) enjoys the same level of respect from me as the member for Hunter. I believe that through the process—and the government is indicating quite clearly there will be further legislation on this—we will get the rest of it right.

The significance of this bill to me, Mr Deputy Speaker, comes from the vast grain growing interests of the Wimmera region of my electorate, and the rolling sandy dunes of the Mallee. As we see it now, thanks to the providence of the heavens, we are very hopeful that just from my electorate we will make a contribution to the GDP this year probably nudging at least a billion dollars.

That is the extent of the interest that I have in a piece of legislation like this: roughly a million tonnes. In the Mallee and the Wimmera we are talking about a region with the potential for up to three million tonnes, if the good Lord will provide adequate rainfall at precisely the right time. So the activities of the Australian Wheat Board are of keen interest to me and my grain growing constituency, and I am very pleased today to have an opportunity to make a contribution on this legislation on their behalf.

As I have mentioned, this bill is the first stage of what will be a new suite of legislation, with improvements and further detail next year. I will be as actively involved and as interested as the member for O'Connor and many other members of this place in what is a very, very significant industry to the Australian interest.

This bill is enabling legislation to set up a process to transform ownership of the Australian Wheat Board to growers. That is something that the industry and the grower organisations they represent have driven themselves. I am willing to acknowledge the member for Hunter's suggestion that the previous government was part of that process. It needs to remember that for years now growers have wanted access to control their own destiny.

BREAK.PARA: The restructure of the Australian Wheat Board brings to fruition a process that goes back seven or eight years now aimed at putting ownership and the control of wheat marketing firmly in the growers' hands, driven by the industry itself, for a very good reason, which I would like an opportunity to point out later. The push for change started in 1989 when industry commenced building up funds for a capital base for a future grower owned Australian Wheat Board via a levy on wheat sales paid into the wheat industry fund. We were grateful for the legislation that enabled that at the time.

As anybody knows who has had association with agropolitics over the years, and particularly the wheat industry, it is like any form of agriculture and any form of commodity in trying to get a geographically diverse constituency together. We have seen the same ingredients with wool, another very significant commodity to the Australian economy. We are currently seeing it now with beef.

It is a difficult process to embrace all of those different interests and the variety of debate to get a consensus. We have that—within reason. The debate that the member for Hunter needs to understand that is going on now is the detail: the assignment of the shares, even the name of the new organisation. I am quite confident that the consultation process and the confidence which the organisations and the growers themselves now have in that process will see us get it right in the final end product.

A key element of the new arrangements is the government's intention that, by 1 July 1999, its only involvement in the wheat industry will be in relation to the export monopoly, which is to be conferred on that independent grower owned company. If you look at the history of the wheat industry, for someone like me who has lived in the Mallee for the majority of his life and my family contacts who are still in grain growing, the history has been a torrid one.
In speaking on a wheat marketing bill way back in 1984, my predecessor, the former member for Mallee, Peter Fisher, said that in the early part of this century:

. . . wheat was being given away at two bob a bushel. There was no stability. Producers were at the whim of a small consortium of buyers who played one grower against the other and reduced an expanding industry to a very sorry state.

That has been the history if you go back 50 years. The impact on Mallee farms in that era is now a matter of recorded history: devastation and people walking off their properties, many of them soldier settlements at that time.

Today, owing to a sensible approach to orderly marketing, the fortunes of the grain industry are vastly different. In our modern era there is a very positive approach. But it has been undergirded by that concept of orderly marketing because of this difficulty of geographic divide, with an industry that spread from the west coast right across to the east coast, and an almost impossible task to get that broad consensus and so many people with different interests together. That has been achieved and undergirded by that concept of orderly marketing which has been provided by the single desk concept.

In 1979, legislation of the Sinclair‐Nixon primary industry ministry portfolio was the most positive for wheat marketing in Australia since the original formation of the Wheat Board. The guaranteed minimum price arrangements gave producers, at long last, a known price for their product. This was achieved at small risk to government, whose only exposure was the contingent liability of guaranteeing the borrowings to support the pool. That is something that these days in the late 1990s governments do not wish to be exposed to, even though it is a very minimal risk. There are other reasons why that link needs to be removed. Growers wish to have control of their own destiny and, by their own monetary contributions now through the levy, established a very significant fund to undergird those borrowings.

But to go back to the guaranteed minimum price, it gave some security because, like many Australian commodities, we are so exposed to the domination of world prices. A crisis in some part of the world creates a crisis for our own growers here, through no fault of their own. But it did give the industry opportunity, through its very good intelligence to a well‐structured, good organisation in the Australian Wheat Board, which has to be in corporate terms regarded as one of our most successful Australian companies. It gave the industry access, in a very organised way, to the market signals and ensured continued productivity and efficiency increases.

It gave growers some security that they would receive a certain price for their commodity whilst they watched it grow and continued to invest in it, with weed control and all the other things that need to be done in any form of agriculture. It gave them some security to adopt some innovative farming techniques and for a gradual restructuring of their industry without the massive trauma, crisis and personal social costs so regularly experienced in many rural areas because of the lack of prospects for the primary industries that undergird the activities of the economy of the small communities in rural areas.

One of the successful things was the 95 per cent up‐front advance providing a high delivery payment which enabled growers to rapidly repay their immediate costs of production. This positive cash flow situation had an ongoing benefit for the surrounding communities, and gave many rural townships some buffer against some of the other rigours that country communities face. A lot of this still continues, and much of the focus of the government's current policy is directed to address this. A fortnight ago we were very proud to announce a very specific policy directed towards advancing Australia's agricultural prospects, which has been received very positively in an electorate like Mallee.

But, as I have said, things have changed for the grain industry. The last decade has seen a greater willingness by the industry to assume greater control of its own destiny, and these changes are now represented in this enabling legislation before us today.

Fortunately, the view today has achieved a lot greater consensus than it did in the very early days. If you go back and read the history, which I wish I had time to read—and I am sure other members and you, Mr Deputy Speaker, would be keen to read the tortuous history of the wheat industry and government's role in it; it is a fascinating history, and I commend readers to it—it involved the parliament, members crossing floors and changing parties. But the end result was a very good result. Most of my growers now speak very highly of the manner in which the Australian Wheat Board has operated.

Of course, there is diverse opinion. Even in my own electorate, there are those who say that if it is time to rejig the industry, let us do it completely and expose it completely to competition and repeal the statutory marketing operations. That is a view I am listening to, but I have to form my final view based on a broad consensus.

Somebody earlier made reference to democracy. Democracy is all about 100 people in one room with a problem to solve. Humans being what they are, you will get 100 different suggestions on how that problem might be solved. At the end of the day, you can get 51 of those people agreeing on one solution and that still leaves 49 unhappy ones. That is democracy. That is the process and that is probably what this parliament is all about.

There are some people who want greater access in our own right to export markets. There is provision for that. There is a permit system within the statutory marketing arrangements that currently exist, that will continue in the new arrangements. If people discover a niche market—whether it be a particular small volume of a particular variety of grain or a market for bagged grain into Asia—and if there is opportunity to put that, there is a permit system.

In fact, tomorrow, the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Anderson) is visiting my electorate for a very large meeting at Warracknabeal, which is roughly the geographic centre of my electorate. I have provided some time for him to see somebody with a particular interest in this; this person does not agree that this legislation goes far enough. I have to accept that he is in the minority in the general view of my constituency. I am supporting the legislation.

There is another reason. In February this year, I had an opportunity to visit the United States. I have been very concerned about the view of the United States Congress. They seem to have a very jaundiced view about the use of the word `board' in the name of the Australian Wheat Board. They have a very near neighbour in Canada whose grain board is very uncooperative in terms of trading arrangements. That jaundiced view extends to their attitude to the Australian Wheat Board.

As part of a brief from my growers, I was able to speak with quite significant congressmen involved in agricultural committees over there. In recent times, my particular visit has received the focus of national attention; I used the provisions provided in members' entitlements via a study allowance to attend that visit. Essentially, the invitation to visit Washington was extended to me by the congress to attend their international prayer breakfast. You might permit me some indulgence here, Mr Speaker; it is relevant to this particular issue.

My objective was to attend that very significant event and represent my constituency and the parliament. It coincided with President Clinton's inaugural celebrations as well. Some members of the press seem to make it their purpose in life to portray members of parliament in a very unfavourable light. I take a very dim view of my use of my study allowance on that visit being considered inappropriate. I suggest that anybody who wishes to make any comment ought to speak with my constituency, particularly the wheat industry, and more particularly the citrus industry, whose interests I very actively pursued during that visit.

Members of parliament, naturally, are fair game for the media. I can accept that we trip up and make a mistake. As long as the reporting is fair and reasonable. I think the attitude of some journalists, and particularly radio commentators, ought to be based more on a principle of fairness. My growers believe that the investment of their taxpayer contributed funds in that visit was appropriately expended.

I found a very interesting view from some very important congressmen. They see the Australian Wheat Board and raise a smokescreen in terms of their own activities in subsidisation and distortions in the trade market—the buyer subsidies. My concern at the time was a $500 million proposal from President Clinton, as a budget provision, to allow for subsidisation. I was assured by the congressman involved that that was simply there to give them some threat against the Europeans, whom they see as bigger rogues than us, and that they would not use those subsidies against their good friends in Australia, and I hope they are up to those assurances.

They have a very misguided view on what the Australian Wheat Board does, contributed to by the fact that we provide them protection via the parliament to have a single desk monopoly on the exporting opportunity. Because of the statutory marketing arrangements which currently exist for the Wheat Board, their concern was that this represents some form of indirect subsidy. That is simply not true. The only exposure to government—as I mentioned earlier—is that listing as a contingent liability which appears when the government guarantees the borrowings for the pool.

What the process will end up with when this enabling legislation is passed and we subsequently introduce the rest of the fine detail, is that the United States will no longer be able to allege that a smokescreen exists. We will have a completely grower owned, grower managed operation in the Australian Wheat Board—or whatever name it comes to be known by later as a new operating company.

I am very pleased to stand here today and represent my constituency. I would like to take the opportunity to congratulate the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy who, unlike the member for Hunter, I would like to assure has gone out of his way to facilitate consultation on this matter and he deserves credit for that. He has done the same with the wool industry and is currently engaged in the same process in the beef industry—both of them are significant primary industries to my electorate. I think that he deserves congratulations and he certainly has them from me. I am looking forward to a very positive process down the track.

From 1 July 1999, there will be an industry standing on its own two feet and in partnership with the government, whose involvement will be in relation to the export monopoly—and for very good reason. On many occasions already the public benefit has been demonstrated. The industry will survive any test that competition policy will place upon it. I would simply urge all members to support this bill and I commend it to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Connor, Gavan, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Let me acknowledge, before I commence my discussion of the Wheat Marketing Amendment Bill, the contribution by the honourable member for Mallee (Mr Forrest). His electorate is certainly one where the wheat industry is critical to the economic survival of the region. I do not think there would be many in this parliament who would doubt his own bona fides as far as wanting the best outcome for the wheat growers and the wheat industry in Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: We are dealing here with one of the major rural primary industries in this country. The wheat industry has been the mainstay of many rural communities across the length and breadth of this country—in Western Australia, Victoria and New South Wales particularly. It is an industry that has made a massive contribution to Australia's economic advancement down through the years.

When you look at Australian primary industry and the big industries, the wheat industry is certainly up there. It has undergone massive change over the period of its existence in Australia. At present nobody on the floor of this parliament would doubt the economic significance of it. Australia, of course, is a major exporter of wheat to the rest of the world. We are the fourth largest exporter of wheat, behind the United States, Canada and the Europeans, and we account for some 10 or 11 per cent of world exports. So we are a significant player. Our exports are focused in very key and strategic markets—the Asian markets, with Japan and China, and the Middle East, with Egypt and Iran.

It is an industry that is facing significant change to the framework in which it has operated historically. It is an industry that is under significant pressure externally, from influences such as the World Trade Organisation and the interests of major wheat exporters from other countries, namely the United States, which has some concerns about the framework in which Australia undertakes the export of its wheat products. Internally, the framework in which the industry has operated is also under challenge from competition policy and the imperatives that that puts on the industry.

It is an industry that is significant but it is one that is in a process of change and the bill before this House extends the process of change that has taken place. The member for Mallee mentioned that this is an industry with an extraordinary and interesting history in terms of the involvement of government in it and the imperatives that gave rise to that involvement. The federal government's involvement goes back to 1915 with the creation of the Australian Wheat Board. As with the involvement of the federal government in the marketing arrangements of many commodities, that involvement was initially necessitated by the deficiencies that existed in the market at that time, which saw the wholesale exploitation of farmers in a corrupted marketplace, and by unscrupulous merchants.

It was the Wheat Industry Stabilisation Act of 1948 that set the framework and the objectives for the industry and the legislation that governs it. That particular act had two key objectives which have set the framework for all that has gone on in this industry and the government's involvement in it down through the years. Those objectives were price stabilisation and the maintenance of predictable and consistent returns to farmers, and the establishment of orderly marketing arrangements to ensure that the corrupted marketplaces did not deliver a bad deal to farmers.

The political party that I represent in this parliament has a long association with wheat marketing reforms. It was the Wheat Marketing Act 1984, with its key change of altering the guaranteed minimum price arrangements to send more correct market signals to producers, that set the framework for reforms that have taken place over the past 15 years. We saw in 1989 the most significant reforms to wheat marketing arrangements. In those particular reforms, we saw the deregulation of the domestic wheat market through the removal of the Australian Wheat Board's compulsory acquisition powers and the termination of administered domestic pricing arrangements. We saw also a removal of the requirement that there be a majority of growers among board members; the establishment of the Wheat Industry Fund; and the expansion of responsibility of the Australian Wheat Board in its ability to trade in other grains.

We are now in another era of reform and, as in the past, the reforms that have been proposed by the previous government and are being pursued by the current government have excited considerable debate among growers of this country, all sections of the industry and within government itself. We are challenged in this new environment that this industry operates in, in the global and domestic sense, to debate fully and to consider fully the arrangements that will propel this industry beyond the year 2000 into the next century.

I find it an odd state of affairs that when this particular legislation was brought back into this House there was a Senate legislative committee process already under way to provide wheat growers and others in the industry an opportunity to air their concerns and grievances as far as what is being proposed with this particular restructuring is concerned.

There has been sufficient disquiet within the industry for the Senate to approve this hearing process, and those hearings, as you would know, got under way in Canberra last week. These hearings are extremely important to the process of consultation between this parliament and the industry itself. They provide the opportunity for the airing of grievance. They also provide an opportunity for the articulation of new perspectives. They have been an important opportunity for many people to highlight potential deficiencies in the marketing and financial structures that are being proposed for the wheat industry in this bill.

I mention here the contribution of the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey) to those Senate committee hearings. We acknowledge on this side of the House that the honourable member is somebody with an intimate knowledge of the industry. He is someone who has had a longstanding interest in it. When the honourable member for O'Connor gets excited about any particular proposals that are being put by any government, I think it is beholden on all of us to sit up and listen to what he has to say.
I was interested in the proceedings of the Senate committee hearing on Monday 15 September, when the honourable member for O'Connor had this to say:
I doubt the need for this particular piece of legislation in any form whatsoever.

It was a fairly strong statement that the honourable member made. I have not read all of the proceedings of that committee, but he has rung an alarm bell. That, in many ways, reflects the diverse opinion within the farming constituencies on the direction of this legislation.

There are some concerns and they have been well articulated by the growers themselves before that particular Senate inquiry and certainly by others on the floor of the parliament in this debate. In the light of the matters of concern that have been raised, my suggestion to the minister would be to look, perhaps, at some alternative marketing and financial structures that would overcome some of the concerns and the problems that are being articulated at this point in time. Certainly, I think that on both sides of the House and within the industry there is a consensus on the need to support the concept of the single desk. Certainly growers themselves have expressed, as many of them always have, their concern for the maintenance of grower control over the direction of their industry.

Growers have expressed some concerns about accessing their funds in the Wheat Industry Fund, which will provide the capital base when the new companies take over the functions of the Wheat Board. There have been concerns raised about the conflicts of interest that might be generated between providing for the interests of growers and the interests of shareholders who might take equity positions when these particular companies are set up. Those concerns have been articulated and I do not propose to go over them here.

In concluding my comments in this debate, let me say that this is a significant industry in this country. It is one which supports rural communities in key states of the Commonwealth and any arrangements that any government makes must be taken after a period of extensive consultation with all the players.

I know the history of this industry is one of great conflict within the industry itself over its direction, and there are those who are arguing for a more pronounced deregulation of this industry to put it on a commercial footing and be more accepting of the global realities as well as domestic realities. However, we on this side of the House will support reasonable arrangements for this industry that are based on the consultative process and on the retention of the single desk, and that do give growers an important say in the future of their industry.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Andrew, Neil, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very happy to follow the member for Corio (Mr O'Connor) in this debate on the Wheat Marketing Amendment Bill . I endorse much of what he said in this debate, although I think it would be only fair to observe that the member for Corio's claim to have had a certain sort of monopoly on wisdom in the wheat industry on his side of the parliament was just a shade uncharitable, given that the changes that occurred in l984, which I very well remember and in which I participated whilst in opposition, were changes that were supported by the opposition. The member for Corio, while he was not here at the time, would at least have to concede that it was the fact that the opposition was prepared to support the then government, in what were politically difficult changes to make, that made it possible for those changes to proceed.

SPEECH.PARA: I would indicate as well to the member for Corio that the political difficulties were much more acutely felt on the coalition benches than they were on the government benches of the day because of the way in which the majority of coalition people were representing affected wheat growers.

Nonetheless, the member for Corio is perfectly right. Here we have a significant, by any standards, Australian export industry. As the member for Corio has said, we are the fourth largest exporter of wheat around the globe. This significant industry is an industry that has been built following the difficulties that it faced through the early part of this century, an industry that has been built on the proposal of a guaranteed minimum price, giving growers price surety, but not necessarily giving them a sensitivity to marketing arrangements.

The changes that have occurred, partly as a result of pressure from the wheat industry and partly as a result of the pressure that we faced from the World Trade Organisation and from the movements into competition policy, have meant that we now have a wheat industry that is obliged not only to be an efficient producer of wheat, in which capacity it has always led the world, but to be an industry that is sensitive to world markets and an efficient marketer as well.

There is always a difficulty for any industry at any time with a scheme that guarantees a minimum price, and even greater difficulties with a scheme that guarantees a cost of production. If I were able, as a legislator, to guarantee a cost of production to agricultural commodity producers and to do it knowing that I was not going to affect their marketing schemes, I would instantly have solved all of the major agricultural problems and I would have every investor in Australia desperate to get into agriculture as a way of guaranteeing forever a return on their investment.

It is, as the wheat industry knows, as the wool industry knows, as the dried fruit industry knows, and as the member for Mallee (Mr Forrest) illustrated, simply not possible to guarantee growers the cost of production. Even a guaranteed minimum price tends to send the wrong signals to producers.

The wheat industry, under pressure from both the WTO and competition policy, is now going through a major restructure. As I said in my response to the remarks from the member for Corio, I was here in 1984 when we dealt with the first step in this restructure, which was the deregulation of the domestic market for Australian wheat. I recall all of the apprehension that was expressed at the time, much of which has subsequently proved to be unfounded. That is not to be critical of it. It is easy to be wise with the benefit of hindsight.

We now have a situation in which we are being pressured to amend our export marketing provisions. This pressure, while it has partially come from the WTO, has been largely resisted by the government but it has wisely agreed that the marketing powers, and the single desk selling arrangements that exist for the Wheat Board, should be retained and should be defensibly retained so long as our competitors have the sort of non‐competition sensitive policies that they have. Make no mistake: there are very few growers around the globe as exposed to global realities as are Australian grain growers. So long as our competitors continue to thwart the market pressures, as they do by sundry and assorted support mechanisms, we should make no apology for the retention of the single desk.

But as part of the commercial reality that is seeping into the wheat industry, as part of the exposure of the wheat industry to the cold winds of market reality, the industry and the government have agreed to restructure the Australian Wheat Board so that we will now have, as other speakers have said, a grower‐owned company which will have, through A and B class shareholders, control of a fund to be known as the Wheat Industry Fund, a fund which I understand currently sits at about $440 million. This fund will provide the sort of surety that is needed to enable growers to be paid in advance for the wheat that they are growing. That very technique of paying in advance out of a grower‐owned fund means that the reality of the market is not something that the growers are insulated from, because the government will no longer be the insulator that has sat between the growers and the marketplace.

There have been some criticisms levelled at the government, and at the way in which we have entertained our involvement with the World Trade Organisation, particularly by the member for Calare (Mr Andren). In participating in this debate, can I say that, uncomfortable as it may be, if we are to continue to be exporters, and if we are to continue to have any sort of say in world export markets, we have no choice but to be participators in the WTO and, through the WTO, in the GATT agreement as it exists. The simple reality is that, in spite of our predominance in the wheat, grain, and wool industries around the world, we remain participators on the world scene with little more than two per cent of world export trade. That means that, as a nation, we have no levers to pull in world export terms. We cannot adjust the settings. We are largely ignored by our competitors. That is why we choose to be participants in the WTO—not to the disadvantage of all Australian producers, as the member for Calare has suggested, but so that those of our competitors who have in the past manipulated their markets to our disadvantage can now be eyeballed by us around the WTO table.

I am the last one to talk about a level playing field. I regret the fact that any such phrase ever entered into the marketing vocabulary, because there is not, and never will be, a level playing field in the corrupt venue of world markets. We should not talk about a level playing field. We should recognise that under the WTO, and under the arrangements that we are talking about today, which allow us to retain some credibility around the WTO table, while there is no level playing field, it is leveller than it has been at any other time in your lifetime or mine. I notice the schoolteacher sitting opposite looking a little bemused at my term `leveller', and I understand his bemusement.

TALK.START.PARA: —More level.

—For want of a better word, it is more level—picking up the member for Stirling's remark—than it has been at any other time. What I am saying to the member for Port Adelaide (Mr Sawford) is that this is the lesser of the available evils and so we ought to pursue it, uncomfortable as it is. While the WTO has obliged on Australian traders and on the wheat industry, in particular, the changes that we are debating here today, we need also to recognise that our adherence to the WTO has gained for us market access in places which were previously closed to us and has given us the opportunity to eyeball competitors who would otherwise treat us unfairly.

SPEECH.PARA: We have nothing to apologise for as representatives of the Australian grain growers, but we need to recognise that our competitors have used the present Wheat Board arrangements as if they were something that we were accessing to their disadvantage. We are now able to eyeball them and say, `We have set the industry apart from the government guarantee that was once in place in order to meet our WTO obligations'; and they, too, are obliged to reduce the sundry and assorted protection mechanisms and market restriction mechanisms that they have in place that have been to our disadvantage.

As my colleagues know, and as I suspect the member for Port Adelaide knows, there is no shortage of illustrations of those markets that are now open to us, or at least more available to us than they were, under the arrangements that the Minister for Trade (Mr Tim Fischer) has entered into and under the arrangements that previous ministers for trade entered into as well. But we are only able to continue to access those markets while we meet our obligations under the WTO, and the legislation currently before us is one step in meeting some of those obligations.

This is legislation that has been controversial. It is legislation that has caused some disquiet in Western Australia. Along with every other member, I am conscious of the comments of the member for O'Connor. I have to say, as a South Australian, that the same sense of apprehension has not existed in my state. In fact, I have had very little lobbying from my constituency, which is largely a wheat growing constituency, about these changes. Most of my growers accept the changes as well‐founded.

I understand the concern of Western Australian wheat growers, because they are such large contributors to the Wheat Industry Fund, but in participating in this debate it would be wrong for me not to mention the degree to which the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Anderson) has shown himself prepared not only to listen to but also to heed the concerns of Western Australian growers and, with legislation likely to come in at a later stage, to endeavour to recognise some of the needs they have for further representation.

My view of the Senate inquiry referred to by the member for Corio is very simple. I privately think the purpose of the Senate inquiry was largely mischievous—it has obviously suited the purposes of the opposition to refer to it—and the amendment that we currently have to this legislation is equally mischievous. The government is well aware of the concerns of some large wheat growers across the nation, particularly in Western Australia. It is not deaf to them, and it intends to heed them so far as it is able, without disadvantaging other growers and without making the scheme unworkable. For that reason I support the legislation and believe the amendment to be unnecessary.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Causley, Ian, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I have to confess, in rising to speak in the Main Committee, that we do not grow very much wheat in Page, being on the north coast of New South Wales. Nevertheless, having been the Minister for Agriculture in the New South Wales government, I have certainly had some involvement with the grains industry across that state. I am well aware of the fact that the Grains Council of Australia has been pushing since 1989 to deregulate the Australian wheat industry in some way and try to make it more modern to compete in the very competitive world that we have just heard about from my good friend the member for Wakefield (Mr Andrew).

SPEECH.PARA: The Wheat Marketing Amendment Bill 1997 is intended to facilitate the transition of the Australian Wheat Board to a wholly owned subsidiary which will eventually become a corporate body to take over the selling of Australian wheat. I know, and we have heard, that there has been some disagreement and some differences of opinion as to what should be the right structures and how this transition should take place. Having dealt with farmers for quite some time, I can assure members that they are very independent people, they all have opinions, and they certainly put those opinions very forcefully.

It is a great effort by the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Mr Anderson, and by Senator Winston Crane, the chairman of the backbench committee. I know Senator Crane has put a lot of work into it. It is a great tribute to those people that we do have a sense of agreement within the industry that this is certainly the right way to go.

I should mention something about the single desk selling because I come from primary industry myself and have quite an involvement in it. There is still a great debate going on as to whether under the competition policy single desk selling is anti‐competitive. I have some grave concerns about the debate at the present time and the directions that it is taking. I do not disagree with competition and efficiencies. In fact, you have to live with them all the time in industries that are certainly at the mercy of world markets. Australia is at the mercy of world markets because of the fact that we export such huge volumes of our product. In most industries at least 80 per cent of our product is exported to world markets and we are at the mercy of those markets.

Nevertheless, we should understand the fact that farmers are not in a position to go out there to barter and bargain with their own product. They really do need a single desk arrangement to get the maximum price for the product that they have. That is not easy because, obviously, when you have a single desk arrangement, there are people within the industry who feel disadvantaged, people who feel that they have a superior product, people who feel they are not getting the maximum for that product and, therefore, probably disagree with the idea that there should be single desk arrangements when selling to the world market.

It came home vividly to me, as Minister for Agriculture for New South Wales in 1994, when I had agreed that the rice industry in New South Wales should have single desk status, and the Japanese went through that terrible typhoon in 1994 where, for the first time, they were going to import rice into Japan. I have to say to you that they were not impressed when they came to Australia and found they had to deal with the Australian Rice Board because they had to pay the price that was commensurate with world market price—the maximum world market price. They could not barter and play one off against the other. They could not drag people down to the lowest common denominator. They had to pay true value for the product.

I think that is what is lost and what is forgotten in some of the argument about competition policy. It is not policy that is disadvantaging the consumer; it is policy that is advantaging Australia to get the maximum value for products. But, having said that, when you have a single desk arrangement there is a huge responsibility on that body to make sure that it takes into consideration all the niche markets that might be available around the world to maximise the price of the product. That is where some of the argument about it has come in. People have a niche market and they believe they can get more value for that product. Therefore, the Australian Wheat Board, or the new corporation, must take that into consideration and be flexible enough to allow that to occur.

I recently had the privilege with the Primary Industries, Resources and Rural and Regional Affairs Committee to interview members of the Australian Wheat Board and go through with them very carefully the arrangements that they have in place for the selling of Australian wheat. I think we came away with the opinion that they were across the issues, that they do give licences to independent people who might be accessing some of these smaller markets to maximise the value, and that they are aware of the responsibility that is placed on them because of the single desk arrangement that they enjoy. But, at the end of the day, I believe it is in the interests of the majority, and probably all Australian producers, to see that they are in a very strong position on the world market.

The United States of America has been mentioned in this debate and I think that we should say something about that because we are tied to the World Trade Agreement. The World Trade Agreement is certainly valuable because Australia does need to access markets across the world. It is a valuable agreement as long as people honour that agreement.

I have been very disappointed in recent days to see some of the actions of the United States of America. I am in no way surprised because we have seen them do this in the past. They are very aggressive marketers on the world scene; they certainly subsidise in their home production areas; and they use export enhancement programs to market around the world. They cause us extreme pain, in many instances, in these world markets.

Because they are a major player, they have a major responsibility to act in a way that is responsible in world markets. It is disappointing, I think, to see some of the actions that they have taken in recent days to inhibit the importation of products into their country. I note that the Deputy Prime Minister, Mr Fischer, has had something to say about that; it does certainly impinge upon the arrangements that we have. We are doing these things in good faith; we in Australia are trying to abide by the World Trade Agreement. We are trying to be good citizens and to have a free and open marketing system. I think it behoves the United States of America to act the same.

I believe that even though my voice is not going to do much to the United States of America, we do have to speak up around the world about what we see as unfair trading. There is a little bit of suspicion in my mind when we see some of the debate on competition policy, because one of the things that worries me is that the debate is often driven by multinational companies. We must watch carefully whether the value that is being reduced on the producing side of some of these industries is in fact transferred across to the consumer. I watch closely some of those, and I start to question whether that is happening. That is one thing that obviously we, as parliamentarians, should be watching closely, because the philosophy of competition policy is that consumers should get a cheaper product.

If that is not happening, then we have to ask ourselves, `Who is gaining from this policy?' If the answer to that is that it is the intermediaries, the big companies, and the people who have the power to manipulate, then I think we should be looking very carefully at what is happening in that particular area. As I said, that leaves farmers in a very vulnerable position.

These arrangements have been mooted for a long time. The industry has certainly worked its way through them. They set up a wheat industry fund to make sure that they had reserves available; the minister is now putting in place this enabling legislation so that the transition can take place; they will have reserves; and the industry itself will have control over its own destiny because of the way the structures are framed.

In fact, with the A class shares, only wheat growers will be able to get A class shares and they will elect the majority of the directors; they can keep control. Those shares cannot be transferred. That is very important; we have learnt that lesson in cooperatives in the past. That is a very important part of the whole legislation. As far as I can see, and as far as I have heard from producers generally, there is an acceptance that this is the right way to go and that there are great benefits in it.

BREAK.PARA: If the debate continues, and if people are still dissatisfied with this single desk arrangement, my only suggestion would be for a dual desk arrangement and no further. A dual desk arrangement would in fact put competition into the marketplace. It could be a private competitor competing against the statutory company that we have at present or the corporate entity that is being formed.

If there are some concerns about competition, it would inject competition into the marketplace as far as the buying of grains from individual producers is concerned. I think that most of the dissatisfaction is probably in the barley industry, not so much in the wheat industry. I know that there is quite a bit of dissatisfaction in the barley industry about the maximising of values in that industry.

As I have said before, if there is total deregulation and if the individual growers have the responsibility to go out and market their product, they neither have the time nor the expertise to do that. If that were the case, I am sure that the big companies involved in the buying of grains across Australia would rub their hands in delight because they could then play one against the other, and they would certainly bring prices down to the lowest common denominator.

That is all I want to say about this bill. I congratulate the minister again. I do not believe that the amendment would add anything to this legislation. I believe this is the right way to go. Obviously, as the years progress, there will be more legislation following to ensure that the transition takes place.
Motion (by Mr Sawford) agreed to:
That further proceedings on the bill be conducted in the House.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 4 September, on motion by Mr Slipper:
That the House take note of the paper.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Quick, Harry, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I am delighted to be able to speak on the motion to take note of the summary report entitled Aspects of youth suicide . I am pleased to note that I will be followed by my friend and colleague the member for Mallee (Mr Forrest), who is the chair of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Family and Community Affairs.

SPEECH.PARA: This report, a very small but very dynamic report, flowed from a very successful one‐day seminar held in the House earlier this year. Experts in the field were able to paint a very accurate and very clinical picture of the trends in youth suicide: methods chosen by males and females; the differences in the success rates between males and females; the suicide rate—capital city, major urban, major rural, remote towns; hospital separation rates and death rates. It is all very clinical and all very statistical. The information is there for us members to use as we seek to compare our Australian figures with those from other countries.

The second half of the seminar revolved around the support services provided by a broad spectrum of non‐government organisations and was a general, broad ranging and very informative discussion on this very important issue. To my mind this was the key part of the one‐day seminar.

BREAK.PARA: What did we find? Firstly, Australia has an absolutely appalling record. We are at the wrong end of the spectrum. Australia, the so‐called `lucky country', has a depressing, almost Jekyll and Hyde psyche when it comes to the issue of youth suicide. Evidence was given at the seminar about the complexities of youth suicide. We were asked: do we bring the topic out in the open? By taking this issue out into the light, do we encourage our at‐risk youth to attempt to solve their seemingly insurmountable problems by taking their lives? Will vulnerable friends of a suicide victim copycat the successful suicide if we focus on trying to work through the reasons why the young person took his or her life? As it states in the report on page 7:

A major part of building effective suicide prevention programmes is recognising the major factors that affect young suicidal people. This will always be a difficult task, as the factors are myriad and complex and not always obvious to those close to a suicidal young person.

That statement is the crux of the whole issue. It worries me and I often ask: why have we got to the stage where our young teenagers find it so difficult to share their feelings and inner fears with their parents, siblings, close friends, teachers or church leaders? Why are so many parents and extended families left wondering after the tragic death of their son or daughter, `Why did they do it'?

It is not just parents, extended family or the deceased peers who wonder why. The teachers who have charge of these young people for probably one‐third of every day of their lives are also left wondering why they have not been able to pick up the signs and perhaps been able to intervene to provide the necessary counselling which might have prevented the tragedy from occurring.

At the seminar, we were informed that there are some significant sociological factors that bear on the possibility of young people attempting suicide. As I read through these, I would ask the people to remember some of the things that have been mentioned in the papers recently.

These significant factors are: firstly, a high divorce rate in the country; secondly, a high youth unemployment rate; thirdly, high female employment; fourthly, extremely high alcohol consumption; fifthly, a high number of unwanted pregnancies and, interestingly, sixthly, low church and religious participation.However, it is important to note that these factors are not of themselves the cause of youth suicide, but they are present in countries like Australia, which, as I mentioned, is at the higher and tragic end of youth suicide statistics.

The seminar was told that events which can trigger thoughts of suicide and potential suicidal behaviour are: the death of a family member or a close friend; divorce in the family or some other major family upheaval; the break‐up of a relationship with a boyfriend or a girlfriend; excessive use of alcohol or some other drugs; physical or emotional loneliness; confusion over sexuality, or rejection because of sexuality. And the last one was the issue of contagion: school friends or peers committing suicide; heroes committing suicide, and media reports of other suicides.

These are the cold facts. The thing that concerns me most is the human dimension of youth suicide that faces our nation. I am sure that all of us in this place can recount stories of young people in our electorate who have chosen to try and end their lives—and so many have succeeded.

When I returned to my electorate last week, a constituent of mine, a good friend, related the story to me that at the weekend her friend came home unexpectedly and, as it turned out, just at the right time. What did she find? She found her teenage son hanging from the ceiling. Because of her unexpected arrival, she happened to be there at the right time. She cut him down and was able to revive him and then take him for medical assistance.

Governments of both political persuasions over the years have allocated considerable resources to try and tackle this problem. The Keating government allocated $13 million for the years 1995 to 1999 for the very successful here for life programs. The Howard government has provided an additional $19 million under what they call the national youth suicide strategy.

Between them, these two programs have set up a series of services to attempt to address the issue of youth suicide—services such as follow‐up for young people presenting to hospitals and health services following self‐harm, and support for GPs and health workers to identify, treat and refer young people at risk of suicide.

It is interesting to note on page 6 of the report that a survey was done by the Jesuit Social Services, and they found a very mixed result amongst hospitals, both in the Catholic and public systems. And it is amazing to me to read that some hospitals have minimal psychiatric and/or psychological care, and have actually discharged suicidal patients with no counselling or follow‐up. That absolutely amazes me. If you had someone, for example, with a rifle involved in some situation of violence there would be immediate reaction and counselling and following up. But because a young person presents at a hospital with slashed wrists or a drug overdose, it is a matter of treat, discharge and you are on your own.

Other hospitals have an established process when dealing with young suicidal people, including mental health assessments and appointments with youth workers and their GP. It makes sense. But why have we got this dichotomy between almost total rejection on the one hand and on the other a considered, socially responsible approach to these young people?

In our report we made three recommendations which, to me, are pivotal to the government's response. Hopefully, once implemented by this government, and supported wholeheartedly by the community, they will result in Australia finally and successfully addressing this horrendous issue. We did something similar with the horrendous road toll in the 1960s, 1970s and early 1980s—and look how successful we have been since we adopted a national approach to the road toll.

Priority 1, as we saw it, was to establish a national advisory council to provide strategic advice to the minister and the government on youth suicide prevention and related matters. The council should be responsible for creating appropriate arrangements for consultation and cooperation between governments and the community at state and territory as well as at federal levels.

Priority 2 states that a research advisory committee should be established to complement the work of the national advisory council on youth suicide prevention. The research committee will be responsible for advising the National Health and Medical Research Council on the management of research projects and research grants, and ensure consistency with national research priorities.

Priority 3 to me is the key to getting an immediate response. It recommends, firstly, the setting up a depression awareness campaign to educate young people and their support networks on how to recognise depression and get help. That is the key—recognising and treating. Secondly, it recommends standard procedures for hospitals to adopt when treating a young person presenting with attempted suicide or self‐harm injuries.

Thirdly—and it has continued to amaze me since I have been a member of this House that we have not done this—it recommends ensuring consistency in data collection at all levels of government. I am absolutely amazed that this just does not happen as a matter of course. When you ask states, it is a mish‐mash. Finally, priority 3 recommends an immediate review of current funding, and redirection of some funds to more appropriate and better targeted programs. There are some excellent programs out there, but they do not have enough in the way of resources, despite the $32 million. Some programs are not working and need to be wiped.

I look forward to bipartisan support for our recommendations and hope that our three priorities are implemented by the end of this year. Unless we do, daily we will be hearing stories in our electorate offices of young people, in the prime of their life, taking their lives because of what, to them, are seemingly insurmountable problems.

I am sure that my friend the chair of the committee, the member for Mallee, who is sitting opposite and is going to speak after me, will be dealing with the problems faced by young people in the rural areas. It is bad enough in the big cities. Once you get out into the small country towns, there are very few services and there are cutbacks by state governments of all persuasions in hospital and community services. If the services are not there on the ground, it is ridiculous to expect a young person, who probably is not of driving age, to access a service in a country town 60 or 70 kilometres away. They need the service in their country town.

I look forward to the government responding as quickly as possible. Hopefully, by the end of this year we can have those three priorities from Aspects of youth suicide adopted and we can say to our young people, `We are going to do something for you.'

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Forrest, John, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —This issue of youth suicide involves us all. I would say, from listening to previous speakers and looking at the long speaking list, that there would not be a member in this House who has not been involved, either as a family member, relative, associate, good friend or parent, with this tragedy of suicide. I am really pleased to be following the member for Franklin (Mr Quick) on the speaker list and I am going to refer to the member for Franklin and me in terms of what is a key element in resolving this difficulty.

SPEECH.PARA: The member for Franklin and I enjoy a good relationship. Somehow we have been able to find a way to bridge the dreadful political void that we often see and experience in the chamber. There are a couple of reasons for that. The mother of the member for Franklin lives in Nhill in my electorate and she reminds me very much of my own mum. Whenever I am going through I always like to drop in and have a cup of tea with her. She is always full of good advice. That is one reason.

The second reason is that I am now elevated to the lofty status of chairing the Standing Committee on Family and Community Affairs which was responsible, under the previous chairmanship of the honourable member for Fisher (Mr Slipper), for conducting a seminar earlier in the year and producing the report which we are commenting on here again today.

Attending that seminar and in the discussions we have had since, we are reminded again of the tragedy that families experience, having to go through self‐doubt and questioning. Parents of young people especially go through the dreadful self‐doubt of `What did I do wrong? It must be my fault,' when very much of what occurs is a mismatch of a society that I think has lost its way a bit. I know the report speaks about every age group and in every age group the issue is awful. But my heart is with the youngsters. These are future Australians who somehow have lost themselves and have sought to end it all as the only option, when really, with the opportunity we have, they should be positive about their future. They should have facilities in their own sense of self‐security to deal with life's difficulties. Nobody wants to pretend that life is not going to be difficult and that there are not going to be crises to confront. For example, there is going to be the first time the most precious gem in your life rejects you at the age of 16 and wants to go out with somebody else. We need somehow to find a way to undergird our youngsters and warn them that this is going to happen and that dealing with rejection is something you need to develop strategies for.

The thing that alarms me is having been close to where a young man committed suicide—only 30 metres from where I slept across the street; we were neighbours. People said they did not see it coming. I think that the clue to resolving all of this is to have some obvious triggers learned by people across the community because we are all going to be part of this. I support the member for Franklin's plea for complete non‐partisanship in respect of this. I really appreciate the very positive way in which members have spoken already and their response to what our committee has put on paper and tabled in the parliament.

I would like to make reference to my own 16‐year‐old daughter who last Saturday night brought home a friend of hers from school. They have developed into really good friends. I had had a busy week in parliament; if you remember what happened last week, all I wanted was a nice quiet night at home to relax and have an early night. But she was concerned about this friend who has already made three attempts to commit suicide. In a sort of desperate plea I said, `Honey, I don't need this.' But we put the time in. We made an investment. Her attitude was, `Dad, I just want to love this person. I love this person and I want you to help me help her.' If we can find a way to trigger that kind of caring concern amongst the school community and amongst the adult community, then I think we will all have achieved a great deal towards addressing the tragedy.

The seminar provided a real focus for the preparation of the report. I do not want to focus as much as the member for Franklin has done on the alarming nature of the statistics that are presented there but we have to accept the fact that in the last 30 years the suicide rate for males has trebled and the suicide rate for females has doubled. I do not want to make that the focus, I want to make the solutions the focus. Our report very clearly, with a priority one rating, recommended:
That a National Advisory Council on Youth Suicide Prevention be established to provide strategic advice to the Minister and the Government on youth suicide prevention and related matters.

That will involve the whole community. I hope that the examples given by the member for Franklin and me might provide some lead. There have been in excess of 25 suicides in my electorate in the four years I have been the federal representative. My observation is that there has to be a caring, concerned group of people who have some insight into the body language and the emotional state that causes somebody to take this step. Those troubled people have to be embraced in a caring community, a caring environment, and they have to feel wanted and needed. It is as simple as that.

It is not complicated. It is not about spending millions of dollars on research and psychoanalysis; it is simply about ensuring that people feel that they are needed and that somebody cares about them. If they have an emotional crisis, whether it be the tragedy of losing someone they have loved, or the tragedy of being rejected by their first girlfriend, they need assistance. We have all experienced the latter. In fact, in my time I have had quite a few.

BREAK.PARA: One needs some strategies to deal with that because rejection is something that human beings have a great deal of difficulty in coping with. The only mechanism to cope with it is if people have a sense of wellbeing about themselves, that they have a regard for themselves as being a person of worth, and that involves a view that can only come from inside a person, almost like their soul, so that they feel good about themselves. Even though somebody else might reject them, they know in here that they are of some worth. It is very much a relationship environment that reinforces that for people.

I saw it happening in my own home last weekend and I can only hope that I can play some part in the bigger picture to extend that very simple example from my own lounge room to the parliament, that we find the key.

In trying to deal with 25‐plus suicides, I have found that it affects everybody in my office. In fact, I have said to my staff, `Do not take any chances if you get a distressed phone call.' On one occasion I jumped in my car and drove 200 kilometres to be there within a few hours, and I am glad I did. It was somebody who was feeling desperate, but all they needed was somebody to take action to share this terrible burden that they had. It turned out to be caused by a government department putting them under enormous pressure, and it was ultimately resolved. We now have a very happy family there.

It will involve us all. I am very pleased to hear the comments of members in this debate. This report has been on the table now for quite a considerable time. It gives us cause to reflect and see what other members are saying. I am very pleased to support the remarks of the deputy chairman, the member for Franklin, and I am looking forward to a very positive response from the government. I urge it to consider the recommendations in the committee's report, adopt them, and proceed from there.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wilton, Greg, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to paint a similar picture to that that the member for Mallee (Mr Forrest) so lucidly and compassionately portrayed to the House. He shares the view I have that basically, whilst many solutions may be put forward to address the issue of suicide per se—both youth suicide and suicide by older persons—people have a strong desire to feel needed, to feel that they are loved, and to feel that they have some worth and role in life. If that can be addressed by greater one‐to‐one counselling, of the kind that occurs in sections of my electorate of Isaacs, primarily through the work of people like Andrew Humphreys, then I am sure that we will, as the member for Franklin (Mr Quick) has said, in adopting a national approach be able to gradually address this most tragic issue that blights our modern society. In fact, not only does it blight our society but in many ways it is perhaps one of the most difficult to tackle.

SPEECH.PARA: The member for Mallee submitted to the chamber an analysis of statistics that deals with the topic that is both alarming and confronting. From a local perspective, the figures are indeed quite shocking. They are particularly concerning in the south‐eastern coastal regions of Melbourne. Let me relate to the Committee figures for the Mornington Peninsula. The rate of suicide is more than twice the state yearly average amongst men. There are some 24.9 per 100,000 male suicides in this region each year, while the average for the rest of Victoria is some 11.2 deaths per 100,000. The picture in the Frankston area is equally as bleak. The number of men taking their own lives annually is 16.6 per 100,000—again, a figure that is well above the state average for the rest of Victoria.

In Cranbourne, where my electoral office is located, as at the end of July this year, nine young people under the age of 25 had committed suicide. This figure is triple the number of deaths that occurred in Cranbourne in the previous three years. The city of Kingston is a municipality that covers much of the federal electorates of Hotham and Isaacs. Suicide claimed the lives of 67 young people in the city of Kingston in 1995, which is up from 45 in the previous year, 1994.

While the picture on a local perspective is quite bleak, the story is similar at an international level. When recently reading the Victorian task force report on suicide prevention, I was most unsettled to learn that it is estimated that in recent years nearly one million people on this planet take their own lives each year. Suicide has consistently remained one of the top 10 causes of death in developed countries in recent history.

While I applaud every aspect of the findings of this most worthy report, I disagree to some extent with the focus on the issue of youth suicide. The biggest group of people committing suicide in society is men aged 25 to 60. Without in any way demeaning the problem of youth suicide, it is clear that, from any objective analysis of the data, the risk to young men does not really commence until they reach the age of 19. I have referred to Mr Andrew Humphreys. Andrew is a youth crisis counsellor at the Chelsea Community and Information Support Centre and has been at the forefront locally of tackling the prickly issue of the high male suicide rate. Andrew points out that, while seven per cent of suicides are teenagers—and this is not an insignificant component—the biggest proportion of deaths does, however, fall in the category of men aged 25 to 60.

An interesting point that Mr Humphreys makes is that the suicide rate for boys when they leave school accelerates, because that is the last time that they enjoy any form of day‐to‐day social interaction and day‐to‐day social support from friends or peer groups on a regular basis.

From the extensive research that has taken place over the last five years, as this problem has been brought out into the open, it becomes apparent that, again as succinctly submitted by the member for Mallee, men kill themselves due to an inability to cope with life events such as relationship break‐ups of the kind that both he and myself have suffered, and unemployment.

On the topic of marriage or relationship break‐ups, Mr Pierre Baume, head of the Australian Institute for Suicide Research and Prevention, is on the public record as saying that in a study of some 4,000 male suicides over 70 per cent were caused by relationship break‐ups and men's subsequent inability to come to terms with the situation. Again as submitted by the member for Mallee, that is a time when men most feel alone, most feel unloved, and most feel that they have got no place in this world.

Clearly, another major cause of suicide is unemployment. An Australian Institute of Criminology research paper into the causes of suicide has shown that a correlation exists between suicide rates and periods of economic turmoil. For instance, during the Great Depression Australia had extremely high male suicide rates. Another example of the effect of economic insecurity affecting the incidence of suicide was the 1987 stock market crash. In the six months after this event, suicide rates were up by 15 per cent.

Other factors include separation from children, childhood trauma and learning disabilities. But as a rule, it is men who cannot talk about their problems, and there are too few services available to them—especially, as the members for Franklin and Mallee have outlined, in Australia's rural and regional areas. Men are often turned away by the all too few support agencies that are there to help, because those services are burdened with other cases.

BREAK.PARA: The discrepancy between male and female suicide rates has increased during the last 30 years and, as those two members have previously indicated, this difference is greatest in rural areas. The overall ratio between males and female suicides is four to one, and the youth ratio is five to one. Men in particular have nowhere to go. Access to counselling services which have a specific focus on combating the propensity for male suicide is sadly lacking, and this needs to be addressed.

The way social supports have been dramatically improved over the last 20 years for battered women provides a good blueprint for what needs to be done. We must tailor our community support services to tackle specific problems, rather than trying a sweeping, broad brush, generalised approach, which will inevitably mean that many seeking help will feel alienated.

Some quite urgent changes do need to be made if we are to cut the number of self‐induced deaths in our society, especially amongst the most vulnerable in our society, those being males. We must extend counselling services within our community to target groups that are not being serviced, and I suggest that that is primarily men in the 25 to 60 age bracket. As an extension of this, it is important that we up‐skill social workers in appropriate assessment and counselling techniques, which have been so sadly lacking in the past.

There must be greater education for both doctors and health service providers within the community about the risk factors which can lead to suicide amongst older men. As the member for Mallee has said, this does not mean that we embark on huge psychoanalytical research papers as to why these things happen. That is not needed. Doctors need to be trained in skilling themselves as to why these events occur, based on people's lack of self‐worth at the times at which they are most likely to take their own lives.

Among the lesser known statistics about suicide in Australia are the high levels committed amongst older men between the ages of 65 and 69. In 1995, there were 15.2 deaths per 100,000 people for men and 3.27 deaths per 100,000 people for women. It is important that, as an institution, parliament should take a closer look at the hidden categories of suicide in Australia. The fact is that until we, as a society, are open and informed about suicide in the most vulnerable of categories—again amongst older males—the pattern of death will no doubt continue unabated.
