A positive aspect to the debate about youth suicide is that we are probably much more capable of tackling this tragedy on a national basis, as the member for Franklin has quite rightly submitted, now that the problem is out in the open and that people are rightfully aware of it. It is to be hoped that in this country such an enlightened approach can now be extended to other forms of suicide which are perhaps less readily acknowledged.

While it is perhaps a little too early for extensive statistical evidence to be processed, the anecdotal evidence that I have received from people in my electorate is that the increasing focus on gambling in Melbourne has led to financial problems in many families. Sometimes the tragic consequences of these strains has resulted in suicide. Figures released by the coroner's office reveal that the number of gambling related suicides has steadily increased since 1992. It is of concern to me that, while over $1 billion is flowing into the state government coffers in Victoria from gambling revenue each year, only about $40 million has been spent on problems with gambling services over the last five years. If we are to tackle the incidence of suicide in society, the issue of problem gambling must be addressed.

I applaud and welcome with open arms the fine efforts of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Family and Community Affairs and its summary report on aspects of youth suicide. I am hopeful that the positive work done by the committee in formalising this report will act as a catalyst for more research into the various other aspects of suicide which, to date, have not been given the amount of attention that I would suggest they so rightfully deserve.

While some factors which lead to suicide are quite hard to quantify, there is certainly a need for our community to work towards an environment in which people feel a sense of belonging and meaning, as the member for Mallee has hit upon so accurately. If we can achieve such a state, then the incidence of all suicides—young or old, male or female—will no doubt be reduced.Unfortunately, it is very hard to create a sense of belonging for people that transcends individual needs and material things in a society which is increasingly obsessed with individual self‐advancement and the attainment of material goods.

I just conclude by stating that, if we can tackle some of the fundamental problems in society, such as the quality of education, unemployment and job security, then there will no doubt be a flow‐on to reduced family breakdowns and, by extrapolation, fewer suicides. Unless we as a society can tackle the fundamental problems and causes of angst in a way that the member for Mallee has suggested, then all the programs in this world and all the heartfelt words of compassion from politicians like the member for Franklin and the member for Mallee will indeed not change a thing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Southcott, Andrew, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak about the seminar that was held here earlier this year, which I attended representing the Minister for Health (Dr Wooldridge). The symptoms of depression have been recognised since antiquity. The Old Testament describes King Saul suffering from a depressive illness and Homer's Iliad gives us the story of Ajax's suicide. Hippocrates actually used the terms `mania' and `melancholia' to describe mental disturbances and other Roman physicians like Celsus and Galen also discovered melancholia. In fact, some of Durer's woodcuts dealt specifically with the subject of melancholia.

SPEECH.PARA: Closer to home, in Australia, those who are familiar with Michael Leunig's excellent cartoons will have seen often that a lot of them actually depict depression. He will often have one of his characters in a small, dark room with a tiny window with just a little bit of light coming in. About five years ago, I heard Michael Leunig speak at the art gallery in South Australia. He talked then, amongst other things, about youth suicide and about how, particularly in Perth, there had been a cluster of suicides that had occurred at one of the private schools there. He described his own suffering that he had had with depression and how it had translated into his work.

It has often been noted that Australia has one of the highest youth suicide rates in the world, and it is truly a tragedy that suicide occurs as commonly amongst 15‐ to 24‐year‐olds as does death resulting from motor vehicle accidents. Thirty years ago, no‐one would have ever believed that the number of deaths from motor vehicle accidents would be almost the same as that from youth suicides. What has happened is that a very efficient public health strategy—through changing people's behaviour with the wearing of seat belts, with random breath testing and with checking people's speeds—has led to a change in behaviour and a rapid decline in the number of 15‐ to 24‐year‐olds who die in motor vehicle accidents. Unfortunately, we have also seen a two to three times increase, since 1970, in the number of young males who are killing themselves.

BREAK.PARA: As far as suicide attempts go, there are almost equal numbers between male and female, but the attempts by young males are often more successful; something like nine times as many young males will actually successfully complete suicide as opposed to females. For every successful suicide attempt, there is something like 40 to 100 unsuccessful bids. What is particularly significant about that is that the No. 1 predictive factor—more than any other factor—of whether someone will actually commit suicide is a previous suicide attempt.

Why do we lead the OECD in youth suicide rates, and why is it particularly high in rural and regional areas amongst our indigenous population? The reasons people attempt or commit suicide are unavoidably complex. While certain sociological influences and mental health background are factors, often the family and friends of the people who commit suicide just cannot recognise what the catalyst was that caused their friends to take their own life.

As the speakers in the seminar highlighted, mental health problems and sociological factors can combine to induce a severe state of depression which, if undetected and untreated, may result in suicidal behaviour. One of the real tragedies of youth suicide is that this depression is completely treatable. The real tragedy is that often the depressive symptoms are not detected and not treated. The cost that that imposes on us as a society is that we are losing part of a cohort of Australia's future.

Professors Cosky and Goldney, in a 1994 study, found that 90 per cent of people who actually committed suicide had evidence of psychiatric illness beforehand. One of the advances that I think we could see in public health would be people being able to recognise the symptoms of depression in their family members, and friends recognising symptoms of depression. Often it is very hard, especially amongst adolescents, to know what is normal adolescent behaviour and what is actually depressive behaviour. Amongst adolescents, depressive illness can be manifest in things like poor academic performance. It can be manifest in drug abuse, antisocial behaviour, sexual promiscuity, truancy and running away. They are all some of the symptoms of depression amongst adolescent children.

A mnemonic to remember the symptoms and signs of depression which I was taught at medical school was `in sad cages'. That was a very useful way of remembering how people manifest with depression: `i' was for a loss of interest; `s' was for suicidal ideation; `a' was for appetite—they often have disordered appetite or complete loss of appetite; `d' was for depression; `c' was for lack of concentration; `a' was for affect—their whole mood was blunted; `g' was for feelings of guilt; `e' was for energy; and `s' was for suicidal ideation.

One of the greatest advances in the area of mental health will be when people recognise it, just as people recognise that when they have chest pain it is a good idea to get to a hospital as soon as possible or that if they are passing too much urine they may have diabetes. It would be useful if people realised that, if their appetite and sleep are disordered or if adolescents are particularly antisocial—perhaps more than normal—it may be something that is treatable without any sort of stigma.

Countries with high youth suicide rates—and the member for Isaacs (Mr Wilton) touched on this—have exhibited sociological factors such as high divorce rates, high youth unemployment, excessive alcohol consumption and low religious participation levels. Perhaps all of those could categorise Australia. They also apply to New Zealand, Canada and northern Europe. What we actually need in Australia is a coordinated program which includes things like primary prevention activities. They are just activities focusing on having a healthy school environment and on having strong families that actually encourage and nurture the individuals within them.

Another area is media strategy. One of the problems with the reporting of suicides in the media is that it has been shown in research that it leads to an increase in suicide rates, especially if there are reports of, say, the hopelessness of people who commit suicide or the method used for the suicide. What is actually needed is for the media to focus on how treatable the depressive and sociological factors can be and also how these people can get help.

Other programs could involve: restricting access to the methods, such as firearms, particularly common in rural areas; school based programs; targeted intervention for high risk individuals—those individuals who are already displaying symptoms of mental illness and those individuals who have already actually attempted suicide—and professional training for all health professionals, including medical practitioners, so that they are able to recognise who is at risk from suicide and who needs follow‐up after an episode of self‐injury or suicidal behaviour.

In addition, personal events which may appear insignificant to the outside world can often have a huge impact on young people and can trigger suicidal thoughts or behaviour. Those personal factors can include: the loss or death of a family member or friend; major family upheavals such as divorce or remarriage; relationship break‐ups with boyfriends or girlfriends; isolation from other people both physically—a problem in rural and remote areas—and emotionally, such as having few friends or low social skills; excessive use of alcohol or other drugs; confusion over sexuality or rejection because of sexuality; and contagion—that is the idea of media contagion where you are surrounded by either friends who suicide or rock band heroes such as Kurt Cobain of Nirvana or media images of people who have committed suicide.

It is worth noting that copycat suicide is not a new phenomenon. Two hundred years ago, Goethe wrote a book, The Sorrows of Young Werther, which was about a young German hero who did commit suicide. That book was banned in several European countries after young men across Europe were killing themselves either dressed in the manner of Young Werther or with the page in the book open at the part where he killed himself. What is modern, however, is the concern that is shared by counsellors, youth workers and researchers alike, that suicide is becoming a more acceptable problem solving option in our society, a notion which is reinforced by media coverage and television and film dramatisation.

At the seminar, Associate Professor Pierre Baume pointed out the large amount of information on the Internet on how to commit suicide. There is not much we can do about actually controlling the information which is on the Internet, but it is important that that negative information on the Internet must be also counteracted by positive information about the early intervention or treatment of depression.

One project which was just recently launched at Flinders University in my electorate of Boothby deals with the early identification and treatment of mental health problems in children and young people, and that project will be jointly managed by Dr Graham Martin of Flinders University and Professor Bob Cosky of the University of Adelaide, who was one of the participants in the seminar. Funded under both the national mental health strategy and the national youth suicide prevention strategy, AusEInet II will establish a national communications network to provide information to services, researchers and policy makers in this area. It will also develop best practice models of early intervention for the mental health of children and young people. Divided into three streams, AusEInet will focus on research, reorientation and relevance.

Having spoken with both Dr Martin and Professor Cosky, I am confident that a network will be established which will have national coverage to make sure that as many people as possible working in this area will have access to the information. Particularly encouraging is that the outcomes of the national youth suicide prevention strategy projects will also be disseminated through a clearing house set up under AusEInet II.

Youth suicide is an ongoing tragedy in Australian society. I commend the organisers for the aspects of youth suicide seminar for addressing this problem and granting it the urgency and importance that it deserves.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fitzgibbon, Joel, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —At 1.30 p.m. last Thursday a funeral was held at Cessnock's John's Anglican Church for 21‐year‐old Jason Bambach. Jason had taken his life the Saturday night before. As is usually the case, Jason appeared to have the world at his feet and appeared happy. He was a gifted footballer who, I am advised, had been approached by the Newcastle Knights. Typically, what went wrong in Jason's mind will probably remain a mystery. My sympathy goes to Cessnock's Jack and Kay Bambach and their families.

SPEECH.PARA: Jason Bambach is likely to be just one of more than 400 15‐ to 21‐year‐olds who will commit suicide in Australia this year. Many more of course will fail in their attempt. Most of those 400 or more have been, or will be, on a proportional basis, from rural and regional Australia—just like Cessnock's Jason Bambach.

There are now three times more young males committing suicide in Australia than was the case in the 1960s. For young females the number has roughly doubled. One of the great mysteries for me is why the suicide rate in Australia appears higher than compared with other developed nations. What does not surprise me is that so many suicides occur in rural and regional Australia.

The Commonwealth spends more than $30 million annually on youth suicide prevention. Much of that money goes to the national youth suicide strategy, which has allocated some $6 million over three years for rural and regional youth counselling services; $6 million to Lifeline and the Kids Help Line; some $3 million for parental programs developed by the Department of Health and Family Services; some $2 million for the education and training of professionals, such as doctors and other health workers, and school teachers; and $1 million over three years for child mental health research, which is designed to at least attempt to determine the factors that lead to suicide amongst our youth.

But while I commend the commitment of both sides of parliament, both the present government and the former Labor government, to the funding of these programs, in a sense—and I do not say this disparagingly—all but the last of the allocations I mentioned is somewhat reactive in its nature. They are commendable, appropriate and essential, but they are somewhat reactive. We will only begin to make ground against this terrible social ill when we get on top of the larger economic issues in this nation. Chief amongst those is unemployment and economic decline in rural and regional Australia, which, in large part, indicates why youth suicide is higher in rural and regional Australia than is the case in our metropolitan areas.

People in rural and regional Australia are continually told that trade liberalisation, competition policy, financial deregulation and privatisation are all good for them. If that is true, and if it is true that all of those reforms lead to higher or faster economic growth, those living in rural and regional Australia are entitled to ask: where is our dividend? Where is the additional commitment to infrastructure projects which create jobs in rural and regional Australia? Where are the greater transport and telecommunications links? These are communities which are dying. Mr Deputy Speaker Nehl, I know that in your own area, in Coffs Harbour and surrounding areas, the unemployment rate is very high, as is the case in the lower part of my electorate.

These communities are experiencing what the experts describe as dynamic decline. It is a vicious circle, usually precipitated by the withdrawal of a reasonably large industry in the town or, indeed, the withdrawal of a government department or the withdrawal of a bank. The withdrawal leads to job losses. Family incomes decline as a result. Consumer spending falls. Other businesses in turn close and further jobs go. Those who can afford to, or who have the ability to, exit the town. Those who are aged or infirm, or who do not have any job prospects in metropolitan Australia, in the cities, remain. The largest industry in the community becomes the local social security office—and even they are now going as well.

The House of Representatives Standing Committee on Family and Community Affairs report titled Aspects of youth suicide is a good report, one that I am sure will go a long way to addressing this terrible social problem. I congratulate the committee on the establishment of the forum held in February. I enjoyed reading the report which came from it. But a comfortable society is a working society, and a greater commitment to jobs by government in this country must come now. It is now not just desirable; it is essential.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bradford, John, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I read the report of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Family and Community Affairs with a great deal of interest. Obviously the problem we have in our country with youth suicide is a very serious one indeed. This report, and the seminar which led to it, is a very worthwhile contribution to our understanding in this country of the serious nature of the problem that we face.

SPEECH.PARA: Unfortunately, as with many of the serious problems we have in our country, it seems to me that we talk a lot about them without actually doing much about them. What we seem to do is to talk about what the problem is and then very often seek to rationalise it or put bandaids on it, rather than getting to the fundamental causes of the problem and doing something about it.

I suspect—and I am not trying to be unkind, because I really do believe this is a valuable contribution—that already we have seen a reaction to this report and to the problem that again seems to me to some extent to be not getting to the fundamental causes of the problem. We have a national youth suicide prevention program in place which will result in the expenditure of a large amount of money. It seems as though the reaction to a problem often is to spend a lot of money on it, and the more money you put into it somehow that is a greater recognition of the extent of the problem.

The solution to some of these problems is money. The solution to many problems is resources, and that certainly has been the reaction to this problem, with a strategy that allocates millions of dollars to rural and regional youth counselling services, millions of dollars to Lifeline and Kids Help Line, millions of dollars to programs for parents, millions of dollars for a youth suicide prevention and education and training program and so on.

I am not condemning that expenditure of money, and it may be helpful. I am sure it could be demonstrated that those things are going to be helpful, but the point is that this report very clearly identifies the causes of the problem. I think Associate Professor Baume's contribution was a very worthwhile one. I know him and I believe the work that he does in this particular area, particularly his desire to establish a national approach to the collection of data, is very worth while. He identifies in his contribution the causes of the problem, and these are they: a high divorce rate, high youth unemployment, high female employment—that is interesting and I will deal with each of these in turn—extremely high alcohol consumption, a high number of unwanted pregnancies and low church or religious participation.

The first problem that Professor Baume identifies is a high divorce rate. I just want to note that. An article came across my desk yesterday which summarises the extent of that problem as well as any other document. The number of divorces in Australia has quadrupled over the past 20 years. Last year, Australia had the highest divorce rate since no‐fault divorce laws were introduced in 1976. We have also recorded the lowest number of marriages per capita this century. Last year, Australia had the third highest divorce rate in the world, 2.9 per 1,000 people, just behind America with 4.6 and the United Kingdom with 3.0. If we accept—Professor Baume makes the point and I think the report reinforces it—that there is a correlation between youth suicide rates and divorce rates, then part of the answer to the problem obviously is to look at the problem of divorce in Australia because it is such a big problem.

When we look at what we are doing about that, one wonders whether our response to that problem is strong enough. At the moment we are talking about making some changes to the Child Support Agency. They are long overdue for those who have been dealing with that particular bureaucracy for a long time. But, again, in a sense they are not the solution to the problem. The Child Support Agency's problems are a product of the high divorce rate in Australia. Even with the wisdom of Solomon, it has become evident to those who have confronted this problem over the years that it is almost insoluble. Ironically, it was Solomon who demonstrated his wisdom, as I recall the story, in the first place by dealing with a custody problem—and his solution was to cut the child in half. Of course, that in a sense solved the problem. I will not go into the story because there is probably not the time here this morning for bible stories. But it is instructive.

We have a problem with divorce, which then leads to our problem with the Child Support Agency bureaucracy. If we did not have the huge divorce problem then we would not have as many problems as we have in picking up the pieces. The problems associated with the level of divorce in Australia can be solved, and that is where our emphasis ought to be. I am not going to speak at great length about that today. It is something I have spoken about quite a bit in the past, but we have to look at the law.

As I said earlier, since the no-fault divorce law was introduced in 1976, we have had this huge escalation, this quadrupling, in the amount of divorce. I am not going to argue here, and nor have I argued in the past, that we wind back the clock to pre‐1976, but we have to recognise that since 1976 we have got this problem. We are dealing with that particular fact.

It has occurred largely because we have made divorce too easy. I recall Archbishop Hollingworth in Brisbane being asked once what he would do about the problem, and his response, when he thought about it for a moment, was very good. He said that he would make marriage more difficult to get into and more difficult to get out of. That is part of the solution to divorce.

Lest colleagues opposite, or even on my side, start getting excited, as some of them do, and particularly some of our female colleagues who are of that bent, and say, `What you want to do is get more women chained to the kitchen sink and be subservient to their husbands', and all that sort of garbage that we hear trotted out when you make these sorts of suggestions, the fact is that it is too easy for people in the current situation to simply walk away from a contract that is entered into solemnly.

No other contracts can be walked away from so easily. We enter into commercial contracts that have sanctions attached, and important as they might be, they are not as important as a life contract that involves the care and nurture of children, in most cases. Despite that, people can suddenly decide today, `I'm tired of this relationship; I want to find the new me; I want to experience new horizons', and so out the door they go. The CSA is knocking on the door the next day and, of course, it is all downhill from there.

There is a connection between high divorce rates, as Professor Baume points out, and the high rate of youth suicide. When we understand that fact and look at all the counselling services, all the millions of dollars that we are expending on worthwhile things, as they might appear to be, we will come to understand that money will not solve the problem.

We need to get to the core of the problem in our country and realise that marriage as an institution needs to be revitalised and that we need to re‐establish the importance of it as a fundamental relationship. We need to stress the importance of families, which is something I speak about in this place quite often, as the fundamental unit in our society. We need to start supporting marriage and placing value on it and making it more difficult for people to walk away from without sanction.

That is the underlying thing. You talk about a contract. This is a relationship you can walk away from without any sanctions. It is not a question of who has caused the problem. I am not arguing that we go back to the days before no-fault divorce law, but I am talking about people accepting responsibility for their actions. In this particular case there is no responsibility accepted for people's actions. There can be a lot done to reduce the rate of divorce in this country.

It is often observed that we also make it very easy for people to get married. I suppose the law reinforces the view that `We will give it a go. If it does not work, then under the law we can just walk away,' which is no way to enter into such a solemn and important and fundamental contract.

That is why there is the need to make sure people understand, through the benefit of pre‐marital counselling and other such opportunities, the importance of what they are doing. I will make a point that I have made before: just look at how much money we spend picking up the pieces after divorce. We spend billions of dollars, one way or another, picking up the pieces after a divorce, whereas we spend so little at the front end, on educating people to understand what the nature of marriage is and providing them with ongoing help and counselling.

Let us get serious about fixing divorce and then we will be addressing one of the fundamental causes of youth suicide. There is no doubt that children suffer from divorce. The trendy view in recent years has been that a good divorce is better than a bad marriage, that kids are okay and that it is a bit like influenza: they will cough and splutter for a few days and then get on with their lives. But the fact is that they do not. Kids suffer from divorce. They suffer not just for a short period of time: the evidence I have seen indicates that they suffer for the rest of their lives. Their children are also likely to suffer because of the impact the divorce has had on their parents. It goes through a number of generations. Kids are hurt by divorce, and ultimately that is what will lead, in some cases, to kids becoming so desperate that they will want to end their agony by unfortunately taking their own lives.

BREAK.PARA: I thought this particular report was useful because it reinforces our understanding of the connection between divorce and youth suicide. I want to make a plea for us to get serious about fixing up the fundamental problem rather than thinking that we should spend more money on all of these other things. As worth while as they may appear to be, they will not solve the problem. It is interesting that we are very keen to stop people smoking because we realise smoking is a health hazard. I make the point very clearly that divorce is a health hazard for our kids. It also makes life harsher for our kids. Kids these days, I think, have a much harsher childhood than perhaps kids of my generation did.

Our parents, as I recall, looking back at my own childhood, may not have got on terribly well the whole time but, in the end, they were very good parents and they stayed together till death parted them. I think we have benefited enormously from that. Kids today, faced with divorce rates of the magnitude that we are talking about, are faced with a very much harsher and more difficult childhood, and that, as we recognise, may lead to an increase in the rate of youth suicide.

I recently read a book by David Blankenhorn, who visited Australia recently, called Fatherless America. While Mr Blankenhorn was here he did a number of interviews during which he talked about America and the importance of fathers to young men. Of course, divorce very often separates boys from their fathers, and we understand the reason for that happening. Mr Blankenhorn said that over 40 per cent of America's children do not live with their fathers, and I suspect that those sorts of percentages are almost being reached in Australia. Before they reach the age of 18, more than half of our nation's children will spend at least some of their childhood growing up without a father in their home. Nearly half of all children living apart from their fathers have not seen them in the previous year. More than 30 per cent of all children today are born to unmarried women. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Forrest, John, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—Not wanting to cheat the member for Corio (Mr O'Connor) of the opportunity to make a contribution I briefly want to respond to the very correct observation by the member for Isaacs (Mr Wilton). He quite rightly asked: `Why is so much of the focus of this report on youth suicide?' The answer is that it was the first initiative of the Standing Committee on Family and Community Affairs. However, I would like to advise him, and all members, that as recently as last Friday, in this very chamber, we had a seminar on men's health. I assure the member for Isaacs that, very clearly, the overwhelming evidence collected will show that—the Hansard will be available as soon as it is approved—adult male suicide is very much a men's health problem, which was his quite correct observation.

SPEECH.PARA: I am very pleased with the activities of the committee and we are very hopeful that shortly we will be able to present, on the table, a report in respect of that particular activity. With the environment of the competitive edge and economic pressures, males are suffering very much from this serious issue, and the member for Isaacs was quite correct to raise his concern. I assure him that it will be addressed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Connor, Gavan, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I congratulate the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Family and Community Affairs for this initiative and for the excellent report it has produced, Aspects of youth suicide . Some of the committee's members are in the chamber today. In looking through this report I was reminded once again of the staggering statistics that it represents. This is a major social problem in this country, and it must be attacked not only by state and federal governments but by the community generally. The community is aware of it and is tackling it, certainly in my electorate.

SPEECH.PARA: Some of the statistics just staggered me, Mr Deputy Speaker. In the statistics quoted here, in 1995 there were 350 suicides by young males and 84 by young females. That is a staggering loss to this nation if that particular statistic is repeated over time. Rates of suicide per 100,000 of population show that since the 1960s, the rate of young male suicides has almost trebled, and for young males in Australia between 1979 and 1995 there has been a fivefold increase in deaths arising from hanging. They are extraordinary statistics, and the report quite correctly homes in on the fact that this problem is endemic in rural and regional areas.

In my particular state we reflect the statistics that are contained in this report. Suicide rates for males have increased dramatically in Victoria, from 5.6 per 100,000 in 1964 to 22.9 per 100,000 in 1995. That is an appalling and staggering increase. While deaths by suicide are most common among males, suicide attempts are most common among women. Here we must look to the causes of this situation—not only why many young people are attempting suicide, but why it is that many females attempt but do not go through with the act, while many males do it and lose their lives.

I guess many in this house have had experience of suicide and youth suicide. I go back to my time before entering this parliament. When I returned to the farm on the death of my father in 1979 I was asked by a local Catholic school to teach part time while I was working on the farm. I spent a lot of time with young people over quite a long period, and I can vividly recall one particular example of a young man who, to all intents and purposes, as the honourable member for Hunter (Mr Fitzgibbon) expressed in his contribution here, had the world at his feet. He was a runner and a bit of a goer and I, along with some other people in the school, spent a lot of time keeping him out of the principal's office.

He was a fine young man who, I would have thought, had he been able to make it through a particular period of his life, would have gone on to be a productive member of his local community and the Australian community. He had a very supportive family and he was much loved by that family. But at the end of the day, for reasons that we will never know, that young man took his own life. That is an experience that many of us on the floor of this parliament have been intimately acquainted with and have had contact with. In a very personal sense, it rocked me to my foundations, and made me aware of the tremendous trauma that is visited not only on families but on school communities and local communities by youth suicide.

Many people have canvassed the reasons, and this report does that. We can go through those. They are many and varied. The honourable member for McPherson (Mr Bradford), who preceded me, quite correctly pointed out that some are within the ambit of government and some are not. I think we have to look primarily at the economic hardship of families and unemployment. That is concentrated fairly substantially in regional areas of this country. That is a major contributing factor. Families in distress are families that are prone to have members commit suicide.

Other factors, as I read the literature, have been advanced: the loss of a sense of community, homelessness, depression, sexual assault, drugs, family conflict and decline in government support services. All of these factors have been mentioned as contributing factors to suicide, particularly youth suicide, in this country.

BREAK.PARA: The Geelong community is aware of this problem. There was a meeting in Geelong on 5 March 1997, which was attended by around 90 people, to deal specifically with this problem. The meeting was convened by the Victorian Premier's Suicide Prevention Task Force and I commend politicians of any political persuasion who show an active interest in this subject.

The message from that meeting was not one, I think, the Victorian Premier would want to hear, because speaker after speaker, of all political persuasions, condemned governments for the massive cutbacks in services that have occurred in rural areas particularly. They sheeted that home as a contributing factor to suicide in rural areas. I do not think we can just narrow that factor down.

The honourable member who preceded me in this debate said that we are perhaps treating this matter after the fact. He made the point that money was not the solution to the problem and he quoted the financial contributions of the previous government and this government in addressing this problem. Maybe it is not so much in the $19 million that this government has allocated, or the $13 million that the previous government allocated, to address this problem but, in a broader sense, the responsibility of government to resource services in rural and regional areas that is able to play a role in combating this insidious disease.

I want to very briefly comment on the Victoria task force report. When it delivered its report it identified the Barwon adolescent task force—BAT force—in my electorate as one of two bodies in the state which was providing a coordinated response to youth problems and addressing this issue.

In my electorate in the Barwon region, the number of youth suicides is well below the Victorian state average. I congratulate BAT force, its committee of management and its network of concerned officers and agencies for their untiring work on behalf of youth in my electorate. It is the BAT force network which has delivered the real support to our youth, which has directly contributed to the situation which was acknowledged in the Victorian government's report.
What was the solution? Why has this organisation been so effective? The chair, Ms Armstrong Rowe, had this to say:
BAT force has built up strong community networks, good communications between agencies and it has well resourced the youth programs that are provided.
I suggest to honourable members that if we are looking to part of the solution to this problem, it includes all the ones that have been mentioned in the report and by honourable members previously.

Part of the solution is correctly resourcing in a financial sense these sorts of organisations that are able to deliver to youth the network of support services that can address some of the real and fundamental problems that youth face before youth go to the point of taking their own lives. I commend this report to all members of parliament and I congratulate those members who have participated in its preparation.
Debate (on motion by Mr Vaile) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The following answers to questions were circulated:

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Mossfield, Frank, MP

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs, upon notice, on 25 August 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: Does Australia have arrangements or agreements with other countries with respect to the deportation of persons from Australia who are convicted of criminal offences; if so, what.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ruddock, Philip, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: Yes. Australia has only one agreement which is with the Government of Cuba. The agreement is in the form of a Memorandum of Understanding (MOU) on Migration Related Issues and was concluded on 24 September 1991. This MOU provides for the provision of travel documents and deportation of persons from Australia to Cuba.
